title: What makes music from the 70s and 80s so much better than today's music? - Quora

response.answer_text: If we are talking about rock and roll, in my opinion there are lots of reasons: 1. Back in the seventies artists played their music on real instruments. Singers were accompanied by real musicians on real instruments. These artists could and did pour their soul into their music. Today too much of recorded music is developed using computer driven equipment that removes the artist from his music and indeed removes the soul from the music and sterilizes it. An electronic drum track or bass line will never replace the man behind the drums or the bass except as a boring line repeated over and over again ad nauseum. 2. The music business was not driven by the marketing departments of the music industry in those days. Artists developed much of their own work and individual styles and if they were lucky, they got “discovered.” Record companies were less afraid to take a chance on a new artist. Some of them resulted in one hit wonders, but a few had music that was accepted with enough popularity by listeners to make them stars. Today’s commercial music is created in the marketing departments of the music industry based on “data” gathered as to what will sell. As an example, when was the last time you heard a female singer sing anything other than ballads? Same for most male artists and in fact there is so little difference between artists in the commercial music of these days it is hard to tell them apart. This goes back to 2010, but have a listen to Supergirly’s Britani Spears parody: SuperGirly_-_Britney_Spears_parody.flv Also, when did you last hear a current-day song about anything other than love. 3. The demise of vinyl 45 single was a contributing factor as well. In earlier days it was comparatively cheap to record and press a pair of songs (often not even by the same artist) on a 45. If the record was a success then the music company could invest the necessary capital to develop the artist's first album. If the single flopped, well, nothing ventured, nothing gained. 4. Until recently, it was much more difficult to break into the music industry if your music was anything other than that which fit into the marketing template of the music company you were trying to impress. It has always been difficult to "make it" in any artistic endeavour, but until recently if you were "different" you pretty well had zero chance. Your chances today also improve by how well you look in the video that your music will appear in. Fat ugly people need not apply. Musicians today must be more like models that musicians. Fortunately, this may be changing with the advent of streaming music sites, Youtube and the like. Unknown artists can post music to any number of streaming sites and see what happens. Any number of off-formula artists have been making a decent living selling as independents. 5. Music of the seventies was individualistic and unique. Artists were much freer to explore different directions within their music. Compare early Beatles music with later ones. Look at how people like Eric Clapton evolved over the years. Look at The Grateful Dead. The range of their music is astounding. Original songs and covers crossed musical borders that are pretty well walls in those days. Today music must fit the formula or it will never even get into the recording studio, much less get air time. 6. Much of modern music, such as rap, is as bankrupt as modern art. I will agree that rap is poetry. Some of it is good poetry, but simply reciting poetry with the hip-hop chant to a background of a monotonous drum and bass track is not music any more than throwing a can of paint at a canvas and calling it art is. Fortunately not all of today’s music is bad. But a lot of it is. Maybe it is one of the reasons that my millennial daughter and her husband choose a 1967 Moody Blues song as there first dance song at their wedding.

It has more to do with the age of the listener than anything else. Think about this subjectively, if you will: music speaks to you about your generation, and most of the music that connects with someone of a certain age also speaks to others of the same age. So, for example, a 16-year old today might not get the symbolism of ‘putting on my boogie shoes’ but might understand ‘getting turnt in da club.’ Musicians of a certain era grow with their audience, and thus, are part of the same cultural touchstones, and are able to speak to listeners of those touchstones. A funk act from the 70’s talking about Watergate or the Civil Rights Movement isn’t going to resonate with kids concerned with Black Lives Matter or Trump. Again, different contexts. That doesn’t mean younger people don’t seek out older music - plenty of them do. It also doesn’t mean that older people don’t still look for newer music to enjoy - plenty of them (myself included) do just that. Anyone who tells you music from the 60’s, 70’s, 80’s is better ‘because people today don’t write real songs’ or just says something like ‘today’s music sucks’ is only saying that because that person no longer understands the context. Anyone who flat-out proclaims ‘oh x and y and z suck it was so much better when I was young and in charge of stuff’, is a person you should avoid at all costs. When listening to music, the most important thing is to keep an open mind. Like it, or don’t like it, but I guarantee you, you’ll find something from 2018 that you love, and you’ll find something from 1988 you’ll also love. These may essentially be the same songs, only written from a difference of 30 years of altered perceptions.

Alot of reasons. I believe music from the 70’s and 80’s was “better” because there was more use of live instrumentation and artists were more adventurous sonically. There were more unique voices and more experimentation with different chord changes, progressions, and bridges. Music was also a lot more melodic back then too and the use of melody makes for good music. Also, the songwriting was much more meaningful. Nowadays, it’s more about how “catchy” a song is versus what the lyrics actually say.

At the very least, there was a like more variety. For one thing, a lot more people actually _wrote their own songs._ Now, most of the hit songs are either by Max Martin or Lukascz Gottwald. And poetry seems to have gone out of style. So there a lot less lyrical variety as well. They're also compressed to death, with the result that human drummers are made to sound like machines rather than vice versa. And there's much less in the way of dynamics or phrasing. With all of those factors, much-of-a-muchness is not the least bit a surprising result.

Why Are We So Nostalgic for Music We Loved as Teenagers? This is a good article. It’s more than just emotional, it’s scientific! As I plod through my 20s, I’ve noticed a strange phenomenon: The music I loved as a teenager means more to me than ever—but with each passing year, the new songs on the radio sound like noisy nonsense. On an objective level, I know this makes no sense. I cannot seriously assert that Ludacris’ “Rollout” is artistically superior to Katy Perry’s “Roar,” yet I treasure every second of the former and reject the latter as yelping pablum. If I listen to the Top 10 hits of 2013, I get a headache. If I listen to the Top 10 hits of 2003, I get happy. Why do the songs I heard when I was teenager sound sweeter than anything I listen to as an adult? I’m happy to report that my own failures of discernment as a music critic may not be entirely to blame. In recent years, psychologists and neuroscientists have confirmed that these songs hold disproportionate power over our emotions. And researchers have uncovered evidence that suggests our brains bind us to the music we heard as teenagers more tightly than anything we’ll hear as adults—a connection that doesn’t weaken as we age. Musical nostalgia, in other words, isn’t just a cultural phenomenon: It’s a neuronic command. And no matter how sophisticated our tastes might otherwise grow to be, our brains may stay jammed on those songs we obsessed over during the high drama of adolescence.
